importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates a current political development regarding European military involvement in Ukraine, particularly in the context of potential ceasefire negotiations and troop deployment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the next two weeks is critical as it marks the window in which a ceasefire deal between Trump and Putin could be reached, potentially triggering the deployment of European troops to Ukraine.

keyTakeAways: Defence Secretary John Healey confirms that European troops are ready to deploy to Ukraine if a ceasefire is brokered by Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin.
The UK and other European nations in the 'coalition of the willing' have developed detailed plans for troop deployment, involving over 200 military planners from 38+ nations.
UK military expenditure for deployment is expected to exceed £100 million, with some funds already allocated for preparation.
British soldiers will be granted new powers to shoot down drones threatening military bases, under a 'kinetic option' policy, which may later extend to civilian sites.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has not been invited to a US–Russian meeting in Budapest but remains open to joining.
Trump reportedly pressured Zelensky to surrender the Donbas region, warning that Putin would 'destroy' Ukraine if such terms were accepted.
Russia has suffered over a million casualties and spends 40% of its government budget on military operations.
European leaders, including Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk and Finnish President Alexander Stubb, have expressed strong opposition to any territorial concessions to Russia.
Finnish President Stubb reaffirmed that Finland would never recognize Crimea, Donetsk, or Luhansk as Russian territory.
Healey stated that Vladimir Putin views Britain as his 'number one enemy' due to UK support for Ukraine.
The risk of wider European conflict has increased, with Healey warning of a 'new era of threat' since the end of World War Two.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Defence Secretary John Healey has confirmed that European troops are ready to deploy to Ukraine within weeks if a ceasefire is reached between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. The coalition of the willing, a group of 26 European nations including the UK, has developed detailed military plans involving over 200 planners from 38 nations, with a projected spending of over £100 million. The UK will grant its soldiers new powers to shoot down drones threatening military bases, a move prompted by drone attacks at US airbases and across Europe. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has not been invited to a proposed Trump–Putin summit in Budapest but remains open to participating. The article highlights escalating tensions over territorial concessions, with Trump reportedly pressuring Zelensky to surrender parts of Donbas, and leaders from Poland and Finland warning against appeasement. Healey also notes that Putin sees Britain as his 'number one enemy' and stresses that the risk of broader European conflict has increased significantly since WWII.
title: Europe 'ready to deploy' troops to Ukraine if ceasefire secured, says Healey
